Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Story: I was just about to take out my trash when I noticed my neighbor, Mrs. Lee, struggling with her own bin. She’s always careful not to overfill it, and I remembered the unspoken rule: don’t crowd the curb with extra bags or use someone else’s space. Our bins were only half-full, but I hesitated, not wanting to seem inconsiderate by putting out more than my share. Just then, my phone buzzed—a new client, Mr. Patel, was calling. He sounded anxious, asking for some quick tips on his new machine. As a repairer, I’m expected to be patient and thorough, even during routine check-ins. I could hear the stress in his voice, and I knew he needed reassurance. But I was still standing in the driveway, trash bag in hand, aware that Mrs. Lee was watching. I felt torn—should I focus on being a good neighbor, or step away to give my client the attention he deserved? The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I stood there, caught between the curb and the call, unsure which role to fulfill first.
